abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Forestry
            Project for Nepal was unsatisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, sustainability is unlikely, its
            impact on institutional development is negligible, and both
            the Bank and Borrower acted satisfactorily. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, components without
            appropriate design and clear operational directives are
            unlikely to do well. Second, the scope of any project and
            the scale of its operations should be based on a careful and
            in-depth analysis of the Borrower's financial and
            managerial capabilities. Third, suitable planting areas
            should be identified in advance, appropriate forest
            management plans with supporting forest inventory
            information should be available, and operational directives
            should be clearly defined. Fourth, effective project
            implementation can only be ensured by appointing an
            experienced and energetic head for the project's
            implementation unit, maintaining continuity in that
            appointment, and establishing close coordination between
            different agencies involved in the project. Fifth, focusing
            on qualitative aspects is important for the impact and
            sustainability of a project in the long run. Sixth, it is
            desirable to identify beneficiaries and organize them in
            small user groups with defined roles, responsibilities and
            harvesting rights from the outset. Lastly, a meaningful
            project impact evaluation is possible only when an efficient
            M&E system is established and information is collected.

docna.cdata!:
Nepal - Second Forestry Project : Credit
            1400 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Nepal - Second Forestry Project :
            Credit 1400 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would support the planting
            of forests on private farms, institutionally owned land,
            waste land, roadsides, river and canal banks, and isolated
            areas of degraded forest land. Other forests would be
            established through an agro-forestry scheme, which would
            permit the cultivation of crops between rows of young trees.
            Areas of natural forest would be rehabilitated through
            better management practices. The project would improve
            support services for these activities by strengthening,
            within the Forestry Department: (a) the organization and
            management of reforestation programs; (b) forestry research;
            (c) monitoring and evaluation; and (d) planning. In
            addition, technical assistance and specialized consultancy
            services would be provided for these activities.
            Opportunities for staff training would be increased by the
            provision of formal and in-service training facilities. As a
            conservation measure, 20,000 fuel efficient stoves would be
            distributed.The major benefits would be increased production
            of fuelwood, timber, poles, fodder, fruits and agricultural
            crops. Additional benefits wuld accrue from increased
            employment opportunities. The project faces no major risks.

The project would support the planting

            waste land, roadsides, river and canal banks, and isolated

            established through an agro-forestry scheme, which would

            Areas of natural forest would be rehabilitated through
